title: Before 1 January 2021, will the European Union delay and/or relax the implementation and/or enforcement of any of its CO2 emission performance standards for new passenger cars and/or new light commercial vehicles?
preds: Going with the crowd on this one, although it seems very unlikely that they will lower the standards.
This week climate action plan announced by EC, with stricter rules for Car Manufacturers dispite their corona lobby. Details will be announced later.
Time has passed and seems like no news or buzz about this is happening that I can find so -7 to probability.

The car industry lobby groups have written to the EU  Commission requesting a rollback on compliance dates for the CO2 emission laws using Covid-19 and the effect the pandemic has had on their business environment.
The European Council for and Energy Efficient Economy have declared their request to be invalid and potentially damaging to long-term sustainability and competitiveness of the European car Industry.
There have been rollbacks by the EPA in the US and requests to the UK Government for tax breaks and relief on emission regulations.
However, the Major German manufacturers VW, Daimler and BMW have stated there is no need to roll-back the requirements that have deflated the argument and so a relaxation or delay of the co2 emission is unlikely. Also, the bureaucratic behemoth that is the EU will not be concerned about the details of a particular department and change will not be sudden. https://www.eceee.org/all-news/news/news-2020/eu-car-lobbys-renewed-attack-on-cars-co2-targets-on-the-back-of-covid-19/  https://www.transportenvironment.org/press/eu-car-lobby’s-renewed-attack-cars-co2-targets-back-covid-19
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/mar/27/carmakers-accused-of-using-covid-19-weaken-environmental-laws

I think it is very unlikely that the EU will change its position on CO2 emissions policy. CO2 levels continue to rise and car makers are accelerating their efforts to increase their introduction of electric vehicles. Europeans are also accepting that our CO2 output needs to be reduced and will oppose changes.
Not with Angela at the helm.
Cutting my forecast in half - it would seem the Greens would have none of this.
Another form of assistance is more likely than stepping back environmental protection measures - subsidies, tax breaks etc

In light of Covid19, the European Union could delay/relax the implementation and/or enforcement of any of its CO2 emissions performance standards  for new passenger cars/performance vehicles. This would be to allow the EU to recover economically from Covid19 before implementing a standard which would contain an economic blow within it. Ultimately this delay will cause a rise in greenhouse gases and a rise in illness, disease, famine, reduction in food and water supplies, war, unrest, and environmental disasters. The future can always be altered by those in power, should they choose to do so.
Highly unlikely in-spite of Covid and the Economy.
Due to the positive, though temporary, environmental impact from the lockdown, and other economic priority, this might take a temporary back-burner.

No, I don't think so. The implementation of CO2 emissions performance standards for new passenger cars and light commercial vehicles is something that has been in the works for awhile, so it doesn't seem like it's something they would relax or delay. The goal was to phase it in by 2020 and to have it take full effect from 2021 and thereafter. There doesn't seem to be much reason for them to halt this forward progress.

Reasons
1. The improved air and environment quality (as a by product of COVID lockdowns) will see greater public pressure to maintain strict emission controls not less.
2. Car prices are not going to be impacted significantly enough by CO2 emission performance standards. Demand will be low regardless.
Cutting my forecast. At some point we'll remember that its the climate that is the thing.
I think the EU wants to hold to the standards as much as possible. The four contrarian companies give it cover to do so.
Based on past buying habits in prior global crisis and the fact that the big 3 German automakers see nonsense in rolling back the CO2 emissions.
I think they will, but not immediately. Still a chance for this year, but suspect they will postpone any lifting of standards to see how pandemic plays out.
If you want to commit political suicide!!!  Some do!!!

The EU is a beaurocratic commission not dissimilar to China that needs approval for major decisions from every one of its members. They will regard the issue as more important than the economic benefit for the car producing countries
economy will be more important than ecology
Stimulus money is going to EV's not ICE's.
Cutting forecast in half, no data to substantiate the assertion that I have seen.

Cutting my forecast in half as I have not seen a convincing arguement that indicates that this is being contemplated or seriously discussed. With six months remaining there is ample time to change my mind if someone has facts. I see the EU focusing on the pandemic and the ravaged economies and how to restore normalicy.
a maioria dos países não está preparada para obrigar as pessoas a comprarem carros eléctricos ou não poluentes e/ou substituir os que possuem por outros menos poluentes.
its more likely that they subsidise cars that fulfil the requirement

Hattip @Leonardthethird for the observation that its both standards and enforcement involved. Standards can be fixed, but enforcement can be modified over time.
This is the kind of thorny issue that bogs MEP's down. At best perhaps temporary relaxations would be premitted as resources are used elsewhere. The pressure to do this will be most intense in 2020.

An S&P analysis [1], notes that while some member countries want to see a reduction in targets overall, it is less than 10% of members at this time. They also note that a selection of automotive industry groups are looking for relief, but looking in other sources, fleet owners are pushing from the other side, saying to keep the rules as-is [2]. With those considerations in mind, it seem unlikely based on current information that there will be a delay or change in the short term. [1] https://www.spglobal.com/ratings/en/research/articles/200429-the-eu-s-drive-for-carbon-neutrality-by-2050-is-undeterred-by-covid-19-11455922
[2] https://www.fleeteurope.com/en/new-energies/europe/analysis/why-ev-uptake-risk-covid-19
Because of the corona crisis' impact on automotive industries
Getting a bit closer to the crowd consensus.

I'd say... "why?"
EU appears committed to the long-term threat of climate change, despite C19. Also, factories are closed, people aren't buying vehicles... *maybe* supply chains are in the market for trucks, but again, why? This isn't the GOP, it is the EU.
If there is something that poking in the eye to the big boy looks like, for Germany this is one of those situations.

Based on this article it sounds like support for delays in the EU parliament is low and I think the EU will see more direct measures as preferable, especially in the short term. https://www.spglobal.com/ratings/en/research/articles/200429-the-eu-s-drive-for-carbon-neutrality-by-2050-is-undeterred-by-covid-19-11455922

The EU will have to consider this in earnest in order to keep the playing field level; to my knowledge the US have already amended their standards:
"In April 2020, NHTSA and EPA amended the Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) and greenhouse gas emissions standards for passenger cars and light trucks and established new less stringent standards, covering model years 2021 through 2026."
https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/regulations-greenhouse-gas-emissions-passenger-cars-and Still, there is a dilemma, which objects to any amendments, when it comes to credibility, reliability and planning dependability about the EU's regulation in general: how can they legitimate to sacrifice the superordinate goal of greenhouse gas emissions reduction for the sake of particular short-term economic interest?
I think it is highly likely that a "pragmatic" approach will outnumber a consistent one...

Took me a few reads for it to register that this identifies both standards and enforcement.  Upon initial read, I was focused only on standards, and I think that a lot of the comments so far may overly focus on same. I think the likelihood that standards will be relaxed is very low. I think that in EU, that ship has sailed.  However, I can see significant potential for relaxing the enforcement (e.g. forbearance of fines) as a place where MEPs and industry might find some compromise. However, given that there is so much stimulus money flying around these days, I also think it is likely that MEPs might say to auto industry "we're not relaxing the emissions standards, but here are X billion Euros for your pain" as a way of avoiding the wrath of greens/liberals, while still handing something to industry.  Very much a WAG, but I put probability of change to standards at 20%, and change/delay to enforcement at 35%. Given that it's either/or, I go with the greater of the two: 35%.

This is even probably an overestimation (which is good, I tend to do the opposite). Whilt the automobile industry is a big and powerful economic block in the European economy, I find it highly unlikely that this would happen, even just when taking taking into account the recent Greeen surge in the European parliament,  and a move like this being very against the cultural (and increasingly) political zeitgeist.
EU is pushing hard for climate change reduction

The automobile industry is one of the most influential interest groups in the European Union. It is one of the backbones of the European economy. That said, I don't think it's a foregone conclusion that they will succeed with relaxing standards. Why? Because there is already backlash by other/adjacent industries that benefit from these regulations [1,2] and the opposition by the car industry is not as unified as it may seem -  notably, Volkswagen, Daimler and BMW remain in favour of the CO2 regulations [3,4]. In addition, before the crisis, EV car sales had increased by 57% in Q1 2020 [5].  There are certainly talks ongoing at the moment - and in the coming weeks and months. Thus, while I don't expect standards to be relaxed, it's not completely improbable that there will be a delay of some sorts. A lot depends on the development of the European economy in the next months. The discussion will probably intensify as soon as or if it becomes clear that companies won't be able to comply with the regulations. Edit: Edited comment for clarity. [1] https://www.theclimategroup.org/news/business-backs-vehicle-emissions-laws-letter-eu-policy-makers
[2] https://www.fleeteurope.com/en/new-energies/europe/analysis/why-ev-uptake-risk-covid-19?a=JMA06&t%5B0%5D=EV100&t%5B1%5D=Fitch&t%5B2%5D=ACEA&t%5B3%5D=COVID-19&t%5B4%5D=IKEA&t%5B5%5D=LeasePlan&t%5B6%5D=Unilever&curl=1
[3] https://www.electrive.com/2020/03/30/european-car-industry-lobby-groups-question-co2-targets-in-the-face-of-covid19/
[4] https://www.transportenvironment.org/press/eu-car-lobby%E2%80%99s-renewed-attack-cars-co2-targets-back-covid-19
[5] https://www.euractiv.com/section/electric-cars/news/electric-car-sales-in-europe-jumped-57-in-q1-2020/
I don't think they want to go backwards now.  If anything compliance could create new jobs.  Auto sales are still going to be weak, which does create pressures for relief.

There is a increasing conciousness  in the european countrys espacially germany (which has a big impact concerning automobile industries)  in the need to embed strict rules against the climate change.
